role.name: For all participants in collaboration plans

item.description:
Channels is an online collaboration planning service.
It enables * analysts to develop best-practice templates for information sharing-enabled collaboration, * planners to setup localized collaboration plans based on collaboration templates, * users to participate in collaboration plans and get collaboration checklists instructing their participation, * administrators to manage the Channels service.

You can * change the spelling of your name, * edit the email address Channels will use to communicate with you * upload a photo of yourself
Make sure you press the Apply button for the changes to take effect.

This allows you to provide the different ways by which your collaborators and supervisors can contact you.
You can select means of communication (email, cell, pager, etc.) and, for each one, give your contact info (an email address, a phone number etc.).

You can change your password by first entering your current one and then entering (twice) an acceptably secure new password.
Don't forget to press the Apply button for the password change to be effected.

Click on the bar to expand the attachment controls. Use the controls to upload a file or enter a URL and then attach it to the current context.
Assign a type to the attachment, the default being "Reference", to indicate your intent. Attachments of type "Picture" will typically be used as an icon.

As a participant or potential participant in a collaboration plan, you may be asked by collaboration template developers to answer surveys in order to help improve a collaboration template.
You can
* see the surveys you need to complete ** and optionally complete them, decline them or forward them, * see those you completed ** and revise you answers if you so wish, * and see those you declined ** and perhaps change your mind about that.

You can
* browse and filter the list of all feedback messages you sent to the developers of the collaboration template your collaboration plan has adopted, * expand the conversation with developers initiated by your feedback, * and add a comment to the conversation.
You can mark feedback as "resolved", once you consider that your feedback has achieved your intended objective.
A glossary of collaboration planning terms

A collaboration plan prescribes how organizations and individuals working for them are expected to collaborate in one or more planning scenarios.
The collaboration is to be realized via the execution of tasks assigned to individuals, based on their organizational roles, and coordinated through communications and information sharing.
Checklists document how to execute each assigned task, including which which communications to make, when how and to who.
A collaboration plan is based on a collaboration template that defines the planning scenarios, the kinds of collaborators, the tasks, the communications that coordinate them, and the checklists for executing the collaboration.

A collaboration template defines a best-practice collaboration between and within organizations in terms of
* tasks required to achieve objectives in identified planning scenarios, * the communications that coordinate and inform these tasks, * how to assign tasks to individuals assigned on the basis of their positions in organizations * checklists detailing how to execute each task and how to coordinate and inform their execution via communication and information sharing
A template identifies the organizations it involves either as ''known organizations'' - real-life organizations - or as ''placeholder'' - organizations which real identities are to be given in the collaboration plans that adopt the template.
A template also identifies the positions (aka organizational roles) that make up the collaborating organizations. Users participate in the collaboration plans based on a template by being assigned to one or more positions defined in the template.
A collaboration template has versions. The most current version is the development version, accessible only to its developers and guests (who can only look but not touch). A development version can be put into production. Plans can only adopt the latest production version of a template.

A collaboration plan involves organizations and individuals holding positions in them (organizational roles).
The organizations known to a plan consist of:
* All the known organizations (as opposed to ''placeholder'' organizations) that are identified in the collaboration template adopted by the plan * All (known) organizations registered in the plan only * All (known) organizations registered in all plans hosted by the Channels service
An organization lists the positions that are relevant to the collaboration and to which it has given roles of responsibility.

The collaboration template upon which a collaboration plan is based identifies all the organizations that are involved in the collaboration it defines. Because each collaboration plan may involve its own, local organizations, template developers will often keep the identity of organizations ''to be determined'' by making them ''placeholder'' organizations.
A placeholder organization from a collaboration template, for example "The Municipal Police Department", can be associated to one or more organizations known to a collaboration plan, for example, "Gotham Police Department".
A collaboration template may identify one of the positions in organizations it defines as a ''custodian'' for a placeholder organization. If so, any user participating in a plan in this position is authorized to associate an organization known to the plan with the template' placeholder organization, in effect, involving the known organization in the collaboration defined for the placeholder organization by the template.
Note that a planner acts as the default custodian for all placeholder organizations.

A position in an organization can be filled one individual and, sometimes, by or more functionally indistinguishable individuals.
A position in an organization usually translates to a job title (e.g. Senior VP Sales) and one or more roles and responsibilities (a.k.a. jobs) on the basis of which task checklists are assigned.
It is possible that by holding a (primary) position in an organization, a user will automatically be assigned to ''linked'' positions in other organizations.
For example, a "Chief of Police" at some municipal police department (primary position) could, according to a template, be automatically assigned to a position of "Member" of the county's "Emergency Operations Center" (linked position). Thus a Chief of Police would have not only the jobs of a chief of police but also all the jobs of a member of the county's emergency operations center.
Users participate in a collaboration plan by being assigned to one or more positions.
How many and which users can be assigned to a given position (and by who) depends on how the position was defined by the developers of the template.
Some positions allow unrestricted self-assignment by users, others require confirmation by supervisors or planners, yet others require some prior, confirmed employment. A position might allow only one user being assigned to it, another might allow any number.
The checklists collaboration checklists a user gets depends on the (accepted and confirmed) positions the user has. The checklists are personalized with the contact names and information of other users participating in positions this user will collaborate with according to the plan.
A plan participant is any user who has accepted to join a collaboration plan, with the intent of being assigned one or more positions in participating organizations

A planner in a collaboration plan is either the user who created the plan or an other user who has been authorized as planner by another planner.
A user can resign as planner (or be resigned by a Channels administrator) but only if he or she is not the sole planner.

If a user is the custodian of a placeholder organization in a collaboration plan, he or she is authorized to manage the association of any number of known organizations to that placeholder.
A user is the custodian of a placeholder organization if he or she is a planner or is assigned to a position that is identified as the custodian by the developers of the template where the placeholder organization is defined.

Organizations and users participate in a collaboration plan.
A known organization defined in the collaboration template upon which the collaboration plan is based automatically participates (as itself) in the plan.
When an organization is registered in a plan, it does not yet participate in the collaboration defined by the template on which the plan is based. Participation by an organization registered in a plan happens when the organization is associated with a placeholder in the template.
When a registered organization is associated with a placeholder organization in the template, the registered organization gets a ''copy'' of all the positions in the placeholder organization.
For example, when "Gotham Police Department" in the plan is associated with "Municipal Police department" in the template, the position of "Chief at Gotham Police Department" is created as a copy of the template-defined position of "Chief of Municipal Police Department".
Users participate in a plan by assigning themselves or by being assigned to one or more positions in participating organizations.
When assigned to a position in an organization by someone else, a user must accept the assignment before it becomes active. Assignment to a position may require confirmation by all users participating in supervisory positions.

Each task in a collaboration has an associated checklist that details how to execute the task. The checklist is defined in the collaboration template of the plan based on the nature of the task, its context and impacts and the communications in and out of the task.
When a user receives checklists from being assigned to positions assigned to tasks, the checklists are personalized with contact names and information of other users who participate in positions the user collaborates with.
A checklist is defined by the nature of the task, what triggers it and by the steps by which the task is best executed.
The triggers can be
* nothing (if the task is ongoing), * information self-acquired (observation of an event, for example), * information to be researched to carry out another task also assigned to the user, * information sent by another user (a notification) * or information requested by another user (a query).
The steps of a checklist can be communications (queries, notifications) or actions (other than communications) taken in executing the task.
A step can be required or optional. It might also depend on another having been completed and on some other conditions being present or absent, such as an information need being satisfied or the task having failed. A step can produce outcomes such as events or new information becoming shareable.
Keep in mind that the checklist is only a document; it is not an interactive to-do list (at least, not yet).

A planning scenario describes anticipated circumstances that would introduce risks an opportunities to organizations who must then collaborate to mitigate those risks and/or seize those opportunities.
A planning scenario is defined as an event of significance (a change that matters somewhere in the world) that might happen, or is happening or has happened, possibly in the context of other event that are happening or have happened.
A collaboration plan might address more than one, presumably related, planning scenarios.

A collaboration requirement specifies expected communication between two organizations in a plan.
The requirement specifies in more or less generic terms: * the ''source'' and ''sink'' organizations, * the information to be communicated * the planning scenario in which this communication is to happen * the number of positions in each organization sending and receiving the information * the number of alternate source-positions for each sink-positions
A collaboration requirement may or may not apply to a pair of organizations in the plan. If it does then, whether or not it can be realized according to the template-defined collaboration is examined and reported.

Business processes (aka workflows) and collaborations are very different concepts, and a collaboration is not necessarily a business process. In fact, bona fide business processes represent the exception rather than the rule.
A ''business process'' is a close orchestration of people and systems within an (extended) organization, all working harmoniously according to a known and repeatable script in order to accomplish a common goal.
A ''collaboration'', as understood in Channels, is the coordination of interdependent work done by multiple individuals, from one or more organizations, each trying to achieve their own, possibly conflicting, goals.
The goals of organizations, namely risk mitigation and opportunity captures, are instantiated by events to be caused, prevented, responded to, recovered from etc. These events, it is assumed, affect, in some ways or other, all the participants in the collaboration, driving them to collaborate and share information.
Collaboration planning focuses on information as the source of task inter-dependencies. Information dependencies are satisfied by communications that either coordinate (start, stop) tasks or inform them so they can succeed.
Unlike business processes, a collaboration plan does not necessarily script the tasks; it only attempts to resolve their information and coordination inter-dependencies via information flows. The collaboration plan assumes that tasks and communications can fail, which is why Channels encourages information flow redundancies in collaboration plans.
Most endeavors involving multiple organizations (each bringing its own agenda) can '''not''' be represented realistically or usefully as business processes. However, most and possibly all multi-organization endeavors can be represented, analyzed and improved upon as collaborations.
It is easy to understand the allure of seeing the work of organizations primarily as business processes. If only we always knew exactly how to work together and always did it predictably and in complete harmony! However, the reality is that only a small percentage of all the work we do with others can be represented as business processes.
So, this is why most of the efficiencies to be gained from planning how we work together will come from improving the flow of information in collaborations, not in business processes.

The ''All Collaboration Plans'' page list all the collaboration plans visible to you, namely, all plans you can participate in and all those, whether or not they are open for participation, for which you are a planner.
You can: * create a new collaboration plan by first selecting the production version of a collaboration template on which the plan is to be based, and then pressing the "Start it" button - you will be the founding planner for this plan, * access a collaboration plan visible to you (select the Go button next to its name in the list of plans).

As a user you can see and all collaboration plans in which you are a planner or that have been opened for participation by their planners.
As a user, you can decide to participate in positions (roughly, organizational roles) that are open to participation by all.
If you created the collaboration plan, you are the initial collaboration planner for this plan. As such, you can authorize other users as planners and, if you wish and are not the only one, resign your planner privileges.
As a planner, you can name the plan, localize it, update it to a new version of the collaboration template, and set collaboration requirements for it.
As a planner, you are automatically a guest of the adopted collaboration template. If you are a guest or a developer of the collaboration template upon which the plan is based, you can access it.
As a planner, you can register organizations for potential participation into the plan (or in all plans), in addition to the known organizations defined by the plan's template (they automatically participate). You can also assign users to positions known to the plan.
If, as a participant, you are assigned to a position where you supervise other positions, you can assign users to these positions, subject to some constraints, and subject to they accepting the assignment. You are also responsible for confirming these assignments in order to activate them.
As a participant, you can access your collaboration checklists, the surveys you take part in, and the replies to feedback you have provided.

You decide whether or not you want to participate in this plan.
If you do, then you can assign yourself or be assigned to positions in organizations participating in the plan.
Assignments to positions will be subject to you accepting and, where appropriate, to being confirmed by supervisors.
Once you participate in a plan, you can withdraw from participation, but only if you are not a planner and if you have not accepted any position.
You user privileges which are either a (potential) participant, a collaboration planner or a Channels administrator.

You can accept to participate in positions that are open to all users or in positions that have been assigned to you by authorized users (planners or your supervisors).
By check a box next to a position (e.g. "Bus driver at Metropolis Transit Operations"), you accept to participate in this position. By un-checking an already checked box, you unilaterally resign the assignment.

Based on your user privileges or current participation, other assignments in the collaboration plan's organization may be available to you.
First select an organization where a desired position would be listed and then select the position.
Your selection may be subject to confirmation by users participating in positions where they supervise the position in which you selected to participate.

This is a list of positions your participation as await confirmation by your supervisors.
You can withdraw your participation request by un-checking the box next to the position.

As a collaboration planner, the ''Collaboration Requirements'' page enables you to define information sharing requirements between organizations participating in the plan.
You can then examine to what extent each requirement can be satisfied by the applicable pairs of organizations (information source-sink pairs), should they follow the adopted collaboration template.
You can add a new requirement definition by pressing the New button in the Definitions tab.
To edit a requirement definition, press on the Edit button next to it in the list of requirements.

The ''Plan Participation'' page enables you to: * browse a registry of all organizations participating or eligible to participate in the plan, * register, as authorized, organizations for participation into the plan (or all plans) as placeholder organizations defined in the collaboration template adopted by the plan, * assign, as authorized, users to template-defined positions in organizations, * confirm the participation of users in positions you supervise, * review, you are planner, the participation issues detected by Channels, * resign your status as collaboration planner (if you are not the only one) and bestow your planner privileges on another user.

The ''All Checklists'' page let's you access all your collaboration checklists and those of all participants you are allowed to see.
If you are a planner, you can see the personalized checklists of all users and the generic checklists for all positions.
If you participate in a supervisory position, you can see the personalized checklists of all users participating in positions you supervise.
By clicking on a position, you access the checklists for those in that position. By clicking on a participant's name, you access the combined checklists for all the positions assigned to the participant in the plan.
Note that for a user who participates in only one position, this page is skipped and the user will be taken directly to the Participant Checklist page.

The ''Participation Checklists'' page displays the combined collaboration checklists:
* given to a user for participation in a position (personalized checklists) * given to a user for all the positions the user participated in (personalized checklists) * for a position based solely on the assigned tasks and required communications (generic checklists - no contact information)
A checklist describes
* a task * what events or communications trigger it (if any) * the steps, with or without constraints, by which the task is executed, including ** actions to be taken ** queries, notifications and receipt confirmations to be made ** self-assigned "research" sub-tasks ** self-assigned "follow up" tasks
A contacts directory, at the bottom of the page, details the contacts of all communications in the checklist.

As a template developer, you use Channels to design and build collaboration templates from which robust checklists are generated that implement robust collaborations.
A collaboration templates forms the basis of collaboration plans where the identities of ''placeholder' organizations are given and where users are assigned to the positions defined in the templates in terms of jobs given to agents in organizations.
A collaboration template specifies how various kinds of organizations ought to communicate and share information to collaboratively prevent, respond to, or recover from a number of anticipated events that test their missions.
Channels continuously examines collaboration templates for gaps and brittleness, and suggests options for remediation.
Channels produces visualizations, analytics and reports that help planners and stakeholders understand and improve complex collaboration templates.
Channels is a ''planning'' tool. It does not manage the ''actual'' sharing of information. It is used to capture and improve the collaboration ''practices'' of organizations and to adaptively produce collaboration checklists.

Channels computes personalized collaboration checklists from a collaboration template and provides them to the plan participants on demand.
As a user's participation in a plan changes, even as events unfold, Channels automatically adapts and updates the user's checklists.

A glossary of collaboration planning terms

A collaboration template is defined by * the planning scenarios that will cause organizations to collaborate and share information * the organizations and agents (stand-ins for people or systems) employed by them that involved in the collaborations * assignable tasks, connected by information flows, that achieve organizational goals in planning scenarios
Applying a scope to a collaboration template produces visualizations, analytics, diagnostics, reports and, crucially, collaboration checklists.
A collaboration template has one editable development version, zero or one production version (read-only) and any number of retired versions (also read-only).
The development version is released by an administrator. Upon releasing a new version of the template, a copy of the development version becomes the new production version and the prior production version is retired. Finally, the development version number is incrementd by one.
Anything that contributes to the definition of a collaboration template, be it a segment, a task, a flow, an entity, information etc. is considered a template element.

An event is an entity representing a transient change in the world that introduces risks and/or opportunities for organizations.
Risks and events should not be confused. An event can introduce risks to one organization while creating opportunities for another.
From the point of view of the template, an event is considered an ''incident'' if its occurrence is not planned (an 'outside' event).

A phase is an entity representing a time period relative to the occurrence of events. A phase is either the time before, during or after events.
A collaboration template can address what happens before, during or after of events, or a combination thereof.
The term ''planning scenario'' is used in collaboration planning to mean a phase of an event being planned for, possibly occurring in the context of other past or current events.

In Channels, a goal is understood as a ''mission-level'' goal of one or more of the organizations to be involved in the template. A goal is either a risk to be mitigated or an opportunity to be seized due to the onset or conclusion of an event.
Goals are achieved by successfully carrying out tasks, or they are automatically achieved when an event terminates.
Mission-level goals are not to be confused with the implied and unstated goals of successfully executing a task or sharing information.

Collaboration templates are composed of one or more or more segments. Each segment addresses a list of organizational goals in one planning scenario.
No two segments should address identical goals in identical planning scenarios.
Two segments are connected by the flows that span them and by how a task in one segment can start or end an events, thus initiating the other segment.

Information is shared by collaborating agents (people or systems) via communication channels.
Information is named and can be described by a list of its essential elements.
Information can be constrained to compliance with a named information product that defines a standard list of elements of information.
Each element of information has a name, can be accompanied by handling instructions and be given a secrecy classification.
A task is an action or decision taken, individually or as a team, by assigned agents (people or systems) in order to achieve goals and/or acquire information to share.

Specification of information needed to execute a task, plus requirements on its manner of delivery.
Delivery requirements include * timeliness * transmission media * information format

Specification of information acquired by or for the execution of a task that could be shared with "quality of service" commitments.
Quality of service commitments include * timeliness * transmission media * information format
How agents who carry out a task that ''produces'' information would commit to share that information with agents carrying out a task that ''consumes'' it.
The list of agents assigned to a task because their profiles match the definition of the task.
The commitment by one agent to communicate based on information acquired doing a task with another agent who needs information to initiate, terminate or successfully execute some other task.

A problem with the template that is either detected automatically by Channels or, upon review, by template developers. An issue is either one of * validity (something is inherently wrong in the template) * completeness (something is obviously missing from the template) * robustness (something is making a plan based on the template likely to fail)

You can attach uploaded or linked resources to a collaboration template or plan as a whole, or to any element of a collaboration template. Attachments can be documents, graphics, videos etc. They can be named and categorized, typically as reference, picture or policy.

An information product is an entity representing a standard bundle of elements of information.
An information product be defined as an extension of another information product to which it adds elements of information.
It is recommended that info needs, capabilities and flows be defined in terms of information products.
An information format is an entity representing a standard format in which information is to be communicated.

An organization is an entity representing an administrative unit (a corporation, an agency, a department, a project team etc.) with a name, a mission, (and possibly a parent organization) and that employs agents in roles of responsibility.

A role is an entity representing a standard set of responsibilities that one or more organizations can assign to some of its members. A role, such as Manager, is different from a job title, such as Senior VP Sales.

An agent is an entity representing a person or system, or a completely interchangeable group of persons or systems.
An agent can be employed by one or more organizations in titled positions, each specified by a role.
Agent ''types'' are not to be confused with ''roles''. Agent types are used to categorize agents independently of their roles. Examples of agent types are "adult", "trained in CPR", "licensed diver" etc.

A place is an entity used to delimit jurisdictions of agents employed by organizations, to locate where tasks are to be executed, where events are of significance, and where a template is meant to apply.

A transmission medium is an entity representing the means, technological or not, by which agents communicate.
A transmission medium can be meant for broadcasting (to all), multicasting (to many) or narrowcasting (to one).

A classification system names secrecy classification levels.
Secrecy classifications are used to specify * the clearances of agents * the secrecy of elements of information * the security level of transmission media

A task with the same name as another task overrides it if it assigns a subset of the agents the other task assigns.
An agent is assigned to the overriding task (the more exclusive one), not the overridden task.

A collaboration checklist is a task assigned to an agent, with attendant activity and information sharing steps detailing its execution.
Checklists are triggered by * observation of events, * notifications (from others or from self), * by requests for information (from others or from self), * or by nothing (ongoing tasks)

An entity is a grab bag term for "timeless things and concepts". Entities include * agents * events * information formats * information products * organizations * phases * places * roles * transmission media
Channels distinguishes between "actual" entities and "types" (or categories) of entities. For example, IBM is an organization whereas "Corporation" is a type of organization.
Entities are automatically created when they are first named in the definition of some template element. No two entities of the same kind can have the same name in a template.
Entities can be categorized by entity types of the same kind (IBM - an actual organization - is a Corporation -a type of organization - but it can not be a Manager - a role).
Categorized entity types form taxonomies (a Police Chief is a Manager is an Employee).
Events, information formats, information products, phases, roles and transmission media are always types in Channels.

Sharing information can impact the execution of tasks in different ways. It can * trigger the task * terminate the task * be critical (crucial) to the task's success * be useful
When doing failure impact analysis, only flows that trigger, terminate or are crucial to the task's success are considered.

A task is considered useful if it directly achieves a goal or if its failure would prevent another task from achieving a goal.
Only useful tasks are considered when doing failure impact analysis. A useless task is considered an issue by Channels.

Template developers can define surveys for various kinds of template elements (surveys about tasks, about events, about the collaboration template as a whole etc.).
A survey is a questionnaire composed of required and optional questions. Questions can have single or multiple answers and they may allow free commentary.
A survey is applied to one or more template elements of the appropriate kind (a task survey can be applied to many tasks) and is then sent to one or more users with an optional deadline.
Recipients of surveys can accept and answer the survey and revise their answers at any time. Recipients can decline a survey or forward it to their contacts, who are then automatically registered as Channels users.

A tag is a word or phrase used to tag template elements in order to informally classify them.
Tags can belong to tag domains. For example, ''esf:transportation'' is the tag ''transportation'' in the tag domain ''esf''.
Tag domains can optionally be predefined by attaching specially formatted text ''tag'' text files to the template.
A given tag can be applied without constraints to template elements of different kinds.
One use of tags is to specify information in collaboration requirements.

A collaboration checklist lists the steps required to successfully execute a task.
A step can be either
* some stated activity (other than communicating) * an information request to make, * a notification to send, * sending confirmation of information received, * a self-assigned research sub-task * a self-assigned follow up sub-task
A step may be required or optional. A step may have identify the completion of other steps as pre-requisites.
A step, to be executable, may also require that some stated conditions (an event phase, a goal having been achieved, an information need having been satisfied, the task having failed) be present or absent.
Channels will raise an issue whenever a condition or outcome from the definition of a task is not referenced by at least one step, for example, when a goal achieved by the task is not associated with a step in its checklist.
The communication steps of a checklist are implied by the flows in and out of a task, to and from other agents(requested info to be received and notifications to be sent).
The sub-task steps are implied by flows to self - research sub-tasks are triggering requests to self and followup sub-tasks are triggering notifications to self.
The conditions on executing steps can be the goals achieved and events triggered by the task, or other stated conditions.
The outcomes of a task (events caused or terminated, goals achieved, sharing capabilities acquired) can be associated with the execution of individual steps.

A function specifies the goals to be achieved, the information needed and the information to be acquired by any task implementing the function.
Functions are "entities" and so they can be categorized by other functions. Functions are always entity "types"; there is no such thing as an "actual" function.
A task may or may not declare that it implements a function. If it does, it is expected to conform to the specifications of the function. Issues are raised if the task does not fully do so.

As a template developer, you can access collaboration template editor and a summary report on all issues found in the template.
As a developer or authorized user you can access the planning surveys you participate in and the feedback you provided.
Documents that have been attached to the template are directly accessible. New ones can be added.
You can switch to another template - or another version of this template - by mousing over the name of the template in the "breadcrumbs" at the top of the page. A drop-down menu of templates will appear. If this page was accessed from a collaboration plan, only the versions of the plan-adopted collaboration template are accessible.

As a template developer, you use the template editor to
* define the scope of the template in terms of risk/opportunity-causing events and of the organizations involved, * compose the template from segments, each one addressing one phase (before, during, after) of one event, and some of the attendant risks/opportunities * define for each segment the information sharing and tasks required to deal with these risks and opportunities * profile the "entities" (events, phases, organizations, roles etc.) referenced in the collaboration template * report issues in addition to those automatically detected by Channels * view analytics to better understand the consequences, strengths and weaknesses of the template

The options are * Presence/Hide Presence - Hide or show the developers presence, activities and messages panel * About Template - Open the template details panel * About Template Segment - Open the segment details panel

The options are * Send message - Send a message about this template as a whole * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste task - Insert the copied task, if any, into the current segment * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this template as a whole * Add new task - Add a new task to the current segment * New issue - Report a new issue about this template as a whole * Add new segment - Add a new segment to this template * Remove this segment - Remove the current segment from this template

The options are * Index - Open the index of all named elements in this template * Tags - Open the panel with all the tags used in this template * Taxonomies - Open the panel showing all entity taxonomies defined in this template * Who's who - Open the panel listing all agents (people and systems) represented in this template * All attachments - Open the panel listing all file and Web page attachments in this template

The options are * All Events and Phases - Open the panel with the editable list of all events event phases in the scope of this template * All Goals - Open the panel showing all goals defined in this template * All involvements - Open the panel used to name the organizations (real or placeholders), the places (actual), information products, formats, roles and transmission media that are expected to be involved in tasks or communication commitments in this template * Classification Systems - Open the panel used to define the security classifications used in this template

The options are * All Checklists - open the panel where all checklists in the template can be browsed * Task Mover - Open the panel used to easily move tasks from the current segment to another (only visible to developers) * Checklists Map - Open a visualization of how agents and organizations are being assigned to tasks and commit to share information - as reflected in their checklists * Template Evaluation - Open a panel containing metrics of all issues found in this template * All Issues - Open a panel listing all the issues found in this template * Template versions - Open a panel identifying the current version of this template and allowing developers to vote on moving it to production

The options are * All feedback - Open a panel where all feedback sent about this template is listed and can be responded to * All surveys - Open a panel from where surveys can be defined, launched and managed

The options are * Send message - Send a message about this template segment * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this segment * New issue - Report a new issue about this segment * Move tasks - Open the panel used to easily move tasks from this segment to another

The options are * Details/Hide details - Show or hide the task definition form * Assignments - Show the list of agents in scope that are assignable to the task given its definition * Overrides - Show how this task overrides or is overridden by other tasks (hidden if N/A) * Failure impacts - Open a panel showing the potential impacts of this task failing * Dissemination - Open a panel showing how elements of information acquired for this tasks disseminate to other tasks * Surveys - Open a panel to launch or access surveys about this task * Agent - Open the profile panel for the agent referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Role - Open the profile panel for the role referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Organization - Open the profile panel for the organization referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Jurisdiction - Open the profile panel for the jurisdiction ( a place) referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Location - Open the profile panel for the location (a place) referenced by the task (hidden if N/A) * Event - Open the profile panel for the event referenced by the task (hidden if N/A)

The options are * Send message - Send a message about this task * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Copy task - Copy this task * Cut task - Copy and remove this task * Set task from copy - Set the definition of this task from the last copied task * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this task * Paste flow - Add copied info need or capability to this task * New issue - Report a new issue about this task * Implement function - Add goals, information needs and capabilities to implement the task's function * Duplicate task - Add new task as a copy of this one * Satisfy info needs - Create all possible flows that satisfy this task's info needs, based on existing info capabilities * Disintermediate - Disconnect this task from all flows where it acts as an intermediary

The options are * Details / Hide details - Open or close the definition form * Info product - Open the profile panel for the referenced info product (hidden if N/A) * Elements - Open the elements of information edit panel (hidden if definition form is closed) * Commitments - Open a panel with all computed info communication commitments (hidden if N/A) * Failure - Open a panel showing the potential impacts of this flow failing (hidden if N/A) * Dissemination - Open a panel showing how elements of informations in this flow disseminate to tasks (hidden if N/A) * Surveys - Open a panel to launch or access surveys about this info need/capability/flow * Send message - Send a message about this info need/capability/flow

The options are * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Copy need/capability/flow - Take a copy * Duplicate need/capability/flow - Add a duplicate need/capability to the task * Remove need/capability/flow - Remove from the task * New issue - Report a new issue about this info need/capability/flow * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this info need/capability/flow * Intermediate flow - Add a "middle man task" between the flow's source and target (hidden if N/A) * Breakup flow - Disconnect the source and target, adding capability and need if implied by the flow (hidden if N/A)

The options are * Show/Hide details - Show or hide the details of this issue reported by a template developer * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Remove issue - Remove this issue (hidden if details not shown) * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this reported issue (hidden if details not shown)

The options are * Send message - Send a message about this template as a whole * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this plan * New issue - Report a new issue about this template as a whole

The options are * Send message - Send a message about this entity * Undo ... - Undo the last change made anywhere in this template * Redo ... - Redo the last undone change * Paste attachment - Add the copied attachment, if any, to this entity * New issue - Report a new issue about this entity

The options are * Send message - Send a message * Delete this message - Delete this message I sent (hidden if message was also emailed) * Email this message / Resend email (hidden if message can not be emailed)

You can see the messages you sent and the messages sent to you.
You can filter out the messages you broadcasted.

You can send a message to all developers, one developer, or all users.
The message can be sent internally within Channels or it can also be sent by email. Note that messages sent only internally can be later deleted by the sender.

This shows the list of all template developers currently working on this collaboration template.
You can also see the list of all authorized developers for this template, whether they are online or not.

This gives you the list of the most recent changes made to the template by yourself and other developers. You can hide your own activities.
You can click on the name of the template element that was changed to quickly navigate to it.

The issues summary report provides metrics on all the issues found in a collaboration template.
The issue metrics are broken down by Robustness issues, Completeness issues and Validity issues.

topic.name: Name all events and phases in scope

item.description:
The scope of the collaboration template is determined in part by the planning scenarios it addresses. A planning scenario is defined in terms of the phase (before, during or after) of an event and by the event itself. For examples, planning scenarios could be responding during an earthquake (the event), or recovering after an earthquake.
The list of all events and phases within the scope of a template thus determines what planning scenarios are within the scope of the collaboration template.
The ''All events and phases'' panel allows you to see all events and phases referenced the template and to directly add new ones, as well as delete any not yet referenced.
The ''Events'' tab gives access to the list of all events in scope. A new event event can be added by naming it. Since the event is not referenced anywhere else (yet) in the template, it is considered an ''incident'', that is, an external event not caused by a planned task. Its ''incident'' status can only be changed once there is a task that causes it. Events referenced in the plan, other than in this panel,can not be removed from the list.
The ''Phases'' tab gives access to the list of all event phases in scope. A new phase can be added by naming it. A phase not yet referenced anywhere else in the template can be deleted.
Note that events can also be named anywhere they are used to define another template element. When they are, they are automatically added to the scope of the template.

Name the '''phases''' within the scope of the collaboration template. Channels will now expect to see at least one segment for each combination of phase and event in scope. The list is part of the template's ''details''.

script.action: Edit list of phases in scope

item.description: Name all the (actual) organizations, places, agents, transmission media, information products and formats that are within the scope of this template and indicate which ones are expected to be involved in tasks (via assignments) or in flows (via communication commitments), and thus be referenced in checklists.

script.action: Edit the list of involved entities

item.description:
All segments in the template are grouped either by event or by phase. They are connected by cross-segment flows and by causation links.
A cross-segment flow is a flow from a task in one segment to a task in another. A causation link is an event caused or terminated by a task in one segment that sets the conditions for another segment.
You can drill down on the cross-segment flows and on the causation links.
From the top action menu, add new segment, then name it and identify the ''planning scenario' it addresses –<small>the phase of one event, possibly in the context of past or current events</small>.–
You can: * name or rename the segment * give it a description * give it tags * attach documents to it * add a new issue

You can: * identify the phase of the event * identify the event * rate the event severity that qualifies an event for this planning scenario * specify a context in terms of other events occurring or having occurred

Define a small number of goals the segment is meant to address. For each goal * set the type of goal, * the organization, type or actual, whose goal it is, * the severity/importance of the risk to be mitigated or gain to be achieved.
Naming the goal is optional.
All goals defined in all segments of the template are presented in a table that can be sorted, filtered and paged.
Define a secrecy classification system to be used in setting * an agent's clearances, * the security of a transmission medium, * the classification level of shared elements of information.

Information flow maps depict how information is consumed and produced by tasks and to what effects.
Represented in a flow map are * Events which initiations or terminations trigger tasks * Event initiated or terminated by tasks * Goals (risks or opportunities) achieved by tasks * Tasks * The information needs and capabilities of tasks * Information sharing flows connecting tasks
Using view controls in the left-hand side, you can * maximize the flow map to occupy to whole browser window, * shrink it to fit in the display space, * simplify it by reducing the amount of information displayed, * hide or show goals, * hide or show info needs and capabilities.
A task is brought into focus for editing by clicking on it in the flow map. Flows can also be opened for editing by clicking on them in the flow map.

Add new task to a segment by clicking ''ADD'' in the Task panel or by selecting ''add new task'' from the top Actions menu. The newly created task is intially empty and presented as ''someone doing something''.

Define a task by * naming it * identifying the function it implements * identifying where it is to be executed * profiling who is to be assigned to it * what goals it directly achieves * and more Note that as little and as much as wanted can be put into a task's definition.

Add an '''information need''' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Receives panel. An info need specifies information that agents assigned to the task need to receive to * trigger the task * enable it to succeed (critical) * terminate the task (useful) * or improve its execution

Add an ''informatio capability'' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Sends panel. An info capability specifies info agents assigned to a task expect to acquire and be able to share with others.

Specify an information need, capability or sharing by * naming the information * requiring the information to be compliant with a named information product * listing its elements * indicating whether it is ''pushed'' (a notification) or ''pulled' (a requested answer) * whether the need, capability or sharing is private or can be made known to parties other than those who need, can share, share or receive the information. * setting restrictions based on the relationships (employment, location, authority, identity) between sources and targets * the communication channels to use, each including transmission medium and, optionally, a required format * timeliness constraints * and more

You can list the essential elements of information of an information need, capability or flow, and set their properties.
The properties of an element of information are * its name * the question it answers * its security classification * its handling instructions * if produced, how it transforms , if at all, received elements * if defining an info need, whether its delivery is subject to timeliness constraints

An information sharing flow connect a tasks that ''produces'' information with a tasks that ''consumes'' it. It is equivalent to connecting an info capability of a task with the info need of another.
A sharing flow is created by connecting an info need or a capability to a task. The flow appears in the ''Receives'' of the consuming task and in the ''Sends'' of the producing task.
Tasks in different segments can only be connected via their respective, defined info need and info capability.
The list of tasks that either override this task or are overridden by it.

A checklist comes pre-populated with steps representing the requested information to be received, the notifications to be sent, the research and follow-up sub-tasks that are defined for the task as flows.
These communication steps can not be removed from the checklist. Action steps, representing simple activities requiring no communication or new information, can be added and removed.
A step can be given: * Prerequisite steps - steps the step must come "after" * Conditions that must be present for the step to be taken ("if") * Conditions that must be absent for the step to be taken ("unless") * Outcomes from the execution of a step
Action steps (not communication steps) can be marked as "required", else they are optional. Communication and sub-task steps are marked as required if they are notifications or follow-ups.
Conditions applicable on steps are either: * Goals achieved by the task * Events triggered or terminated by the task * Information needs of the task * The task having failed (a non-optional condition for "on-failure notification steps) * Conditions ''local'' to the execution of the task added to the checklist - they can also be removed
Outcomes of a steps can be: * Goals, if any, achieved by the task * Events, if any, caused or terminated by the task * Sharing capabilities acquired for or from successfully executing the task
A checklist must be confirmed to be deployed to participants as such. Any change to the implied communication steps or to the action steps requires a re-confirmation.
A process flow describing the execution of the checklist is accessed by clicking on the flow icon next to the name of the task.

The checklist flow diagram depicts how the steps in the checklist are to be executed.
The green dot represents start of execution and the red dot its end. Execution is from left to right.
Steps that can be executed in parallel are depicted in parallel. Steps that must precede one another are depicted in sequences.
Steps that are executed conditionally are preceded by ''if'' and/or ''unless'' conditions. If there is more than one condition constraining a step, the conditions precede the step in a sequence.
The outcomes of steps are shown linked to the steps.

Define an event (always a type, never an actual event) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with event types * locating where it would happen * stating whether the event can terminate on its own * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All events are listed in '''All events'''
Events can be found by name in the template's index.
Define a phase (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * specifying if it is a pre-, co- or post-event phase * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All phases are listed in the template's '''details'''.
Phases can be found by name in the template's index.

Define an actual or type of organization by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with organization types * If an actual organization, by ** naming the parent organization ** listing the agents it employs, with titles and roles, and optionally jurisdictions and supervisors Note that all profile attributes are optional.

An actual organization can be declared as a placeholder, meaning that its possibly many real-world identities will be set by communities adopting the template.
One or more known organizations in a collaboration plan can participate as the planned placeholder organization. The participating organization inherits (a copy of) the agents employed by the placeholder.
The custodian of a placeholder organization an the agent authorized to register known organizations as the placeholder. Whoever in a plan participates as this agent is an acting custodian. Collaboration planners are by default acting custodians.

This diagram shows how this organizations fits within a hierarchy of parent organizations.
Selecting an organization opens its profile.
Define a role (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Roles can be found by name in the template's index.

Define an actual or type of agent by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with agent types * If an actual agent, by ** declaring it a person or system ** setting clearances, languages, availability ** setting constraints on users participating as this agent * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Agents can be found in the template's ''who's who''.
Agents can also be found by name in the template's index.

Users in a collaboration plan participate as (actual) agents that are defined in the collaboration template the plan has adopted.
Depending on the participation constrains set for the agent, * any number of users can participate as the agent * or exactly one user can participate * or at most a specified number of users can participate
Furthermore, who can participate as the agent can be set to * any user whatsoever (open participation) * or users confirmed in their participation by other users participating as the agent's supervisors * or users already participating as agents employed by one of the agent's organizations
Participation can be anonymous, in which case the names and contact information of participating users will not appear in the checklists of other users.

This diagram shows how this agent fits within a hierarchy of supervisors.
Selecting an agent opens its profile.

Define an actual or type of place by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with place types (such as 'city', 'building' etc.) * if an actual place, by ** naming what place it is within ** giving a street address and postal code ** identifying its geographical area * if a type of place, by ** setting the place (type or actual) it must be in ** the place it must contain * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Places can be found by name in the template's index.

Define a transmission medium (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * stating whether it is unicast, multicast or broadcast * naming the other media this one can delegate to * naming its level of security * giving the pattern the media's ''addresses'' must conform to * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Transmission media can be found by name in the template's index.

Define an information product (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * defining the elements of information flows standardized to this information product require * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Information products can be found by name in the template's index.

Define an information format (always a type) that can qualify communication channels by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Information formats can be found by name in the template's index.

Define a function that tasks can implement.
A function can be: * named * described * categorized by other (more generic) functions
A function defines the kinds of goals, if any, a task implementing it is expected to achieve, as well as the information needs and information capabilities that such a task is expected to have in order to conform to the function.
The goals specified by a function are goal categories plus whether they are risks to be mitigated or gaines to be made.
The information needs and capabilities specified by the function are named, optionally point to an information product, and define function-specific elements of information.
When a function is categorized by other functions, it adds to the goals, information needs and capabilitites that the categorizing functions define.
Functions can be found by name in the template's index.

A collaboration template determines how agents must commit to share information with one another.
Commitment networks depict these communication commitment relationships between agents either directly or aggregated by role or organization.
You can drill down on each commitment relationship to see the communicationg commitments it summarizes.
You can see what organizations have agents assigned to a segment's task and how these organizations are linked by communication commitments.
You can see the different ways in which this entity is involved in the template, and then drill down.

Issues may have been detected or reported about this entity's profile. You can include issues about other template elements that relate to the entity. You can also filter out issues that have been waived by template developers (the default).
You can browse a paginated table of these issues, filter them, sort them and drill down on them.
To create or view an existing survey about the resolution of this issue, click on the survey icon.
You can visualize where, according to template, individual elements of informations comsumed by a task would come from, and where elements of information produced by a task would end up.

You can visualize how the failure of a task or of a flow can cause the cascading failures of useful tasks, thus jeopardizing the achiement of organizational goals.
Only useful tasks and critical flows are considered when doing failure impact analysis.

Channels automatically detected issues about this template element. You or other developers may also have reported issues about it.
All issues about the template element are listed. The developer-reported issues can be opened up to edit their names, description, severity and remediation options. When editing remediation options, start each one on a new line.
Some issues detected by Channels can be waived (marked as false positives).
You can report a new issue by pressing the New button and then editing the issue. When describing remediation options, start each one on a new line.
You can automatically create a survey about remediating an issue by pressing on the ''Create survey'' button. If a survey was already created, you can view it by pressing the the ''View survey'' button.

The current production and development versions for this template are identified.
You can vote to move the current development version of this in production if you believe it is ready. You can see the votes of other template developers and send them messages. Note that only an administrator can actually put the current development version into production.

The template evaluation gives an accounting of the issues found in this template. The metrics are expressed in terms of * the three main types of issues (robustness, completeness, validity) * their severity * whether they were waived or not * and how many different kinds of issues were found
All issues found in the template are listed in a paged table. You can sort them, filter them, search on their names and drill down on them.
An obvious way of improving a collaboration template is to resolve issues detected by Channels and by planners. The 'All issues" table aggregates all individual issues found in a template.
Metrics on all issues found in a template provide a sense of the current quality of the collaboration template.
If the resolution of an issue is not self-evident and requires input from stakeholders, a survey (with questionnaire) can be created about resolving the issue.
When too many tasks are added to a segment, the segment becomes difficult to manage. To shrink a bloated segment, a new segment is usually created and tasks are moved to it.

Collaboration checklists are computed by assigning agents to tasks and by deriving communication commitments from the flows connecting assigned tasks.
A key concern is making sure that the right agents get assigned to the right tasks, and that only the right agents that are assigned to the tasks on each side of a flow become parties to communication commitments.
Which agents are assigned to a task is determined by * how a task specifies the agents assignable to it * what agents are in the template's environments and how they are profiled * how the agents are employed (role, jurisdiction, organization) * how the taxonomies of role, agent, organization etc. are defined

Exactly what communication commitments are generated for a flow depends on * what agents are assigned to the producing task and consuming task connected by the flow * what restrictions are put on pairing agents into commitments (the committer and beneficiary must be in the same organization etc.) * whether an overriding flow prohibits a pairing of agents

script.action: See communication commitments derived from a flow

item.description:
Entities (i.e. roles, agents, organizations, places, events etc.) can be categorized. Agents are categorized by agent types, organization by organization types, events by other events (events are always types) etc.
How entities are categorized largely determine the meaning of the tasks, flows, employments etc. that are defined in terms of these entities.
The meaning of a template boils down to the task assignments and consequent communication commitments (checklists) that are implied by the collaboration template.
Even a small change to the taxonomy (a.k.a. typology) or roles, for example, can cause widespread changes to the checklists computed from a template, and thus its meaning.
Taxonomies are defined implicitly by categorizing individual entities. The best way to verify that taxonomies are correct is to visualize them.

A ''flow map'' shows tasks connected by flows where each flow can imply a potentially large number of communication commitments. The ''checklists map'' makes it easy to see if the sharing commitments generated from the template are the intended ones.
The map is focused on one agent or one organization (as an aggregate of agents). It shows the commitments that involved that egent or organizations.
The other parties to the commitments can be aggregated by role, organization type or not at all.
Clicking on an assigned task navigates to the task's definition and opens the checklist flow diagram for this task.

All the checklists (one for each task in the template) are listed, to be sorted on the task names, segment names and their confirmation status.
Checklists can be filtered to see only the ones confirmed or not confirmed, or to see only the checklists in a given segment.
Clicking on the name of a tasks or a segment, takes you to it.

You can enlist the help of stakeholders via surveys. A survey is a questionnaire about elements of the template or the template as a whole.
You compose questionnaires by adding, ordering, editing etc. statements and questions. Questions can be marked as required or optional.
A questionnaire applies to the template as a whole or to one kind of template element (template questionnaire, task questionnaires, event questionnaires etc.)
Questionnaires can be activated and deactivated. They can be extended while they are being used in surveys.
A survey is launched on the template or on a template element by applying a questionnaire to it.

script.action: View launched and launch-able surveys on a task

item.description: Once a survey is launched, it can be managed by * inviting users to participate * looking at the answers from survey participants * deactivating or reactivating the survey * editing the survey's questionnaire

Surveys can be launched on an issue that was detected. The questionnaire is automatically generated based on the remediation options.
The questionnaire can be modified and extended while the survey is ongoing.
An issue remediation survey is automatically deactivated when the issue disappears.
Note that the issue remediation questionnaires are by default not shown in the list of all questionnaires; a checkbox must be checked to see them.

Once a survey is launched, users can be invited to participate in it. Users can be given a deadline to answer all of the survey's required questions.
After the deadline has passed, the survey is considered late. Late participants can be ''nagged'' (nags are sent by email).
A participant can *accept the invitation by answering questions, *decline the invitation *forward the survey to others (if it was marked as forwardable).
Note that anyone who is forwarded a survey and who is not yet a user of Channels is automatically given a login, password and limited access to the template as a participant.

topic.name: Lookup the results of a survey

item.description:
As participants in a survey answer the questionnaire, results are compiled and made available to all template developers.
Results can be viewed by opening the survey and selecting the Results tabs.

Users can ask questions, report problems and make suggestions via a feedback widget that appears in their home page, their checklists etc.
You can see this feedback and reply to it. The user can then reply back etc. or mark the question, problem or suggestion as resolved.

Every element of a template that has a name can be found from the index.
The index can be filtered by kind of element (role, agent, event etc.), by tags, and by partial name.

Every employement of every agent is aggregated in the ''who's who'' table.
The table can be indexed by the name of the agent or by attributes of employment (organization, role, location of employer).

Documents and Web pages of various types (policy, reference, picture etc.) can be attached to the template and any element in it.
A table with all attachments in the template can be found in the template's ''attachments''.

The template and every element in it can be tagged.
The list of all tags used in the template can be looked up to see what has been marked by any given tag.

The entity types used to categorize roles, agents, organizations, places, events etc. (entities) can themselves be categorized to create taxonomies.
Changes to a taxonomy can have profound impacts on the collaboration checklists that are generated by the template.
Taxonomies can be visualized to verify that they are correct.

Whenever a template element is referenced by name in the definition of another, there will also be a link to get to the referenced element's definition.
Also, most forms used to define an element of the template contain a table listing and linking to all other elements that reference it in their definitions.
For example, at the bottom of in the profile of a role is an index of all other template elements that reference the role or that match the role.

script.action: Open the a role profile to see its references

item.description: You can report an issue about the current context by pressing the New button, and then * providing a brief description of the issue * giving the type of issue (validity, completeness or robustness) * optionally tagging the issue * rating the severity of the issue * giving options for its remediation (start each option on a new line)

As an administrator, you manage templates and users for a Channels server.
Template management consists of:
* Creating a new template with a unique resource identifier (URI) * Deleting a template - permitted only if not yet adopted by a collaboration plan * Putting the current development version of a template into production * Naming the owner of the template * Changing the default email addresses at which user or developer feedback is sent
User management consists of:
* Adding a new user with a unique username - be aware that users can not be deleted, only disabled * Giving a user a full name, email address and password - the user can later modify all of these * Making the user as an admin * Disabling the user - this can be later reversed * Giving the user developer vs guest (view-only) status for specific collaboration templates.
Make sure to press the Apply button for changes to take effect.
